partrace package¶

Submodules¶

Useful constants imported in other modules

partrace.disk module¶

Useful analytic functions for a typical disk. Use of this library is deprecated.

partrace.disk.get_Omegak(r, z)¶

keplerian frequency

partrace.disk.get_T(r, z)¶

vertically isothermal approx

partrace.disk.get_Tmid(r)¶

Tmid powerlaw

partrace.disk.get_diffusivity(r, z, alpha=0.001)¶

return the diffusivity of the gas

partrace.disk.get_dpdr(r, z)¶

radial pressure grad approximation

partrace.disk.get_eta(r, z)¶

gas velocity differential

partrace.disk.get_pressure(r, z)¶

local pressure

partrace.disk.get_rho(r, z)¶

local density (from surface density)

partrace.disk.get_scaleheight(r)¶

scaleheight of gas

partrace.disk.get_sigma(r)¶

Surface density

partrace.disk.get_soundspeed(r)¶

soundspeed in gas

partrace.disk.get_velocity(r, z)¶

get subkeplerian gas velocity

partrace.disk.perturbed_sigma(r)¶

Perturbed disk profile a la Alarcon et al 2022

partrace.disk.unperturbed_sigma(r)¶

unperturbed surface density

partrace.grid module¶

Class for regridding mesh onto cartesian grid.

Use of this is NOT recommeded, instead use mesh.interpolators to get data as needed at a given location. Once interpolators are made slow-down is negligable, plus interpolation on the cartesian grid would have to be done anyway.

class partrace.grid.Grid(fargodir, nx, ny, nz=1, domain=None, nout=- 1, quiet=False)¶

Bases: object

Cartesian regrid from fargo mesh input

regrid()¶

partrace.integrate module¶

Functions to help with integration of particles in the mesh

class partrace.integrate.Solver(status, times, history, sol)¶

Bases: object

Helper class for ODE solution

status¶
status of solver.
-2 = other
-1 = fail
0 = success
1 = particle reached inner edge of mesh
2 = particle reached outer edge of mesh
3 = particle was accreted onto planet
Type

int

times¶

long array of output times from solver

Type

array (nout,)

history¶

long array of output variables

Type

array (nout,y.shape)

sol¶

rk45 solver just in case

Type

solver

partrace.integrate.add_diffusion(particle, rk)¶

Helper function to add random diffusion to integration

partrace.integrate.fun(t, Y, particle, planet)¶

Time derivative at time t of 6d pos vector Y.

partrace.integrate.integrate(t0, tf, particle, planet=None, savefile=None, **kwargs)¶

Do the integration for particle in a mesh including a planet from time t0 -> tf. Calls the function solve_ode()

Parameters

  • t0 (float) – start time of integration

  • tf (float) – end time of integration

  • particle (Particle) – particle class that will be integrated in time

  • planet (Planet) – Planet to consider if there is one in the mesh default: None

  • savefile (str) – if not None, output integration results as compressed npz file with name savefile

  • kwargs (optional keyword arguments to pass to solve_ode()) –

    This includes:

    max_step : float rtol, atol : float or array_like vectorized : bool

Return type

Solver object

partrace.integrate.one_step(particle, planet, **kwargs)¶

Debugging function to take only one step at a time.

partrace.integrate.solve_ode(fun, t0, y0, tf, args=None, savefile=False, **kwargs)¶

ODE solver including random diffusive movement. Similar in practice to scipy.integrate.solve_ode, but with added diffusion in solver.

Parameters

  • fun (function) – time derivative of y, of form fun(t,y,*args) = d/dt y(t)

  • t0 (float) – initial time of integration

  • y0 (float or (n,) array) – initial conditions

  • tf (float) – end of integration. sets direction of integral

  • args (tuple) – args to pass to fun(). If only one arg, format like args=(arg,)

  • kwargs (optional keyword arguments to pass to RK45 solver.) –

    This includes:

    max_step : float rtol, atol : float or array_like vectorized : bool

Return type

Solver object

partrace.mesh module¶

Main backbone of partrace implementation. The Mesh class takes in FARGO3D output from a given directory and save the data for the scalar variables as a mesh. By default, Mesh is in the same coordinate system as fargo output, but data can all be determined from cartesian inputs using supplied functions.

class partrace.mesh.Mesh(fargodir, states='all', n=- 1, quiet=False)¶

Bases: object

Fargo domain mesh. Contains the domain, density, energy and velocity mesh.

Parameters

  • fargodir (str) – directory where fargo output data can be found

  • states (str, list) – list of states to read in from fargooutput. If states==’all’, then states of [‘gasdens’,’gasvx’,’gasvy’,’gasvz’,’gasenergy’] are read in. If states==None, then no states will be read in. default: ‘all’

  • n (int) – which number output to read. i.e. gas density will be read in fargodir/gasdens{n}.dat. If n==-1, then the last output will be read. Values are saved in Mesh.n dictionary for each state. default: -1

  • quiet (bool) – print confirmation messages to stdout default: False

fargodir¶

directory where fargo output data can be found.

Type

str

ndim¶

Number of dimensions of fargo data.

Type

int

quiet¶

If messages are suppressed.

Type

bool

state¶

Dictionary containing (nz,ny,nx) ndarray of scalar variables. These are read from the fargo output data.

Type

dict

interpolators¶

Dictionary containing scipy interpolator objects for each of the state variables in state.

Type

dict

n¶

Dictionary containing int of output number for each state. Ideally, all n values are the same and this is redundant, but if n = -1 is used, this can check that all the data is read in from the same output.

Type

dictionary

n{x,y,z}

Number of fargo cells in {x,y,z} where | if coords == cylindrical: | “x” = azimuth | “y” = radius | “z” = z | if coords == spherical: | “x” = azimuth | “y” = radius | “z” = polar

Type

int

{x,y,z}centers

Array of length {nx,ny,nz} containing the cell centers stored in coordinate system of FARGO.

Type

ndarray

{x,y,z}edges

Array of length {nx+1,ny+1,nz+1} containing fargo cell edges.

Type

ndarray

confirm()¶

prints confirmation message from mesh creation

create_interpolator(state)¶

Creates the interpolator function using scipy interpolate If the dimension of the mesh is 2d then interpolator will be 2d, this avoids issues with interpolating from a single z component

get_Omega(x, y, z=0)¶

return keplerian frequency at given cartesian location

get_diff_grad(x, y, z=0)¶

Return the cartesian gradient of the diffusivity

get_diffusivity(x, y, z=0)¶

Determine the diffusivity (aka viscosity) at a given location D = alpha*cs*H = alpha*H**2*omega = nu

get_domain(ghostcells=True)¶

Reads in domain.dat files and creates arrays of cell edge and cell center values. Also determines dimensionality of output.

get_gas_vel(x, y, z=0)¶

Return the cartesian gas velocity at given location

get_rho(x, y, z=0)¶

Determine the density at a given location

get_rho_grad(x, y, z=0)¶

return the cartesian gradient of the density

get_scaleheight(x, y, z=0)¶

return the scaleheight at given cartesian location

get_soundspeed(x, y, z=0)¶

Return the soundspeed at given cartesian location

get_state_from_cart(state, x, y, z=0)¶

Get the value of ‘state’ at a given cartesian coordinate

plot_state(state, ax=None, log=True, itheta=- 1, yunits=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Create 2d plot of state and return image

read_state(state, n=- 1)¶

readin the grid data for output ‘state’ at output number n. Default n=-1 gives last ouptut.

This is called automatically in __init__(), but can be called by the user to update n value or readin new files.

read_variables(n=0)¶

Reads variables.par file and cretes dict of variables. Also read in from summary0.dat to get scaling laws

partrace.particle module¶

Particle class for tracer particles that move through the Mesh.

class partrace.particle.Particle(mesh, x, y, z, a=0.01, rho_s=2)¶

Bases: object

A particle that can move through the disk. Particles are initialized with velocity equal to the gas around them.

Parameters

  • mesh (Mesh) – partrace mesh object that contains disk information for the particle to move through

  • x (float) – starting location for the particle

  • y (float) – starting location for the particle

  • z (float) – starting location for the particle

  • a (float) – particle size in cm default: 0.01 cm

  • rho_s (float) – particle density in g cm-3 default: 2.0 g cm-3

a¶

particle size in cm

Type

float

rho_s¶

particle density in g cm-3

Type

float

mesh¶

Mesh object the particle is embedded in

Type

Mesh

pos¶

current cartesian position of particle

Type

ndarray (3,)

vel¶

current cartesian velocity of particle

Type

ndarray (3,)

pos0¶

initial cartesian position of particle

Type

ndarray (3,)

vel0¶

initial cartesian velocity of particle

Type

ndarray (3,)

get_centAccel()¶

Centrifugal acceleration vector due to rotating frame

get_dragAccel()¶

find the epstein drag acceleration vector

get_drag_coeff()¶

drag coefficient Tanigawa et al. 2014 (Watanabe+Ida 1997)

get_gravAccel()¶

find the acceleration vector due to the star gravity

get_newer_dragAccel()¶

Get stokes drag acceleration vector

get_particleDiffusivity()¶

Particle diffusivity, Youdin & Lithwick 2007

get_planetAccel(planet)¶

grav acceleration vector due to planet

get_stokes()¶

get the stokes number at the current location

get_stokes_grad()¶

return the gradient of the stokes value at the current location

get_vdiff()¶

Calculate the diffusive velocity based on diffusivity gradient where: vdiff = d/dx D = d/dx Dg/(1+st^2)

get_veff()¶

determine the effective velocity of the particle including diffusive effects from diffusivity and density gradients

get_vrho()¶

Calculate the diffusive velocity based on density gradient where: vrho = D/rho * d/dx[rho]

total_accel(planet)¶

Get total acceleration acting on the particle

update_position(x, y, z)¶

update the position of the particle

update_velocity(vx, vy, vz)¶

update the velocity of the particle

partrace.planet module¶

Contains planet class for planet embedded in mesh

class partrace.planet.Planet(mesh, planet_no=0, name='planet')¶

Bases: object

Planet embedded in mesh, information is read in from planet{planet_no}.dat in mesh.fargodir

Parameters

  • mesh (Mesh) – Mesh object that planet is embedded in

  • planet_no (int) – planet number to read in data from. planet is read in from mesh.fargodir/planet{planet_no}.dat. Mesh.n is used to get planet location data consistent with mesh. default: 0

  • name (str) – name of planet for tracking if there is more than one planet in mesh default: ‘planet’

mesh¶

Mesh object that planet is embedded in

Type

Mesh

name¶

Name of planet for tracking

Type

str

fname¶

Name of fargo output file with planet data

Type

str

nout¶

output number for planet data

Type

int

pos¶

Cartesian position of planet

Type

ndarray (3,)

vel¶

Cartesian velocity of planet

Type

ndarray (3,)

mass¶

Mass of planet

Type

float

time¶

Time of output in seconds

Type

float

omegaframe¶

Rotation rate of Mesh

Type

float

hill¶

Hill radius size

Type

float

bondi¶

bondi radius size

Type

float

envelope¶

size of planetary accretion envelope

Type

float

get_bondi_radius()¶

determine the bondi radius of the planet

get_envelope_radius()¶

determine the envelope radius around the planet

get_hill_radius()¶

determine the hill radius of the planet

read_data()¶

reads in data from planet file and stores as class values

Module contents¶

partrace.create_grid(fargodir, nx, ny, nz=1, domain=None, nout=- 1, quiet=False)¶

Create a cartesian re-grid from Mesh. Deprecated

partrace.create_mesh(fargodir, states='all', n=- 1, quiet=False)¶

Create a Mesh object from FARGO3D output.

Parameters

  • fargodir (str) – directory where fargo output data can be found

  • states (str, list) – list of states to read in from fargooutput. If states==’all’, then states of [‘gasdens’,’gasvx’,’gasvy’,’gasvz’,’gasenergy’] are read in. If states==None, then no states will be read in. default: ‘all’

  • n (int) – which number output to read. i.e. gas density will be read in fargodir/gasdens{n}.dat. If n==-1, then the last output will be read. Values are saved in self.n dictionary for each state. Ideally, all n values are the same and this is redundant, but if n = -1 is used, this can check that all the data is read in from the same output. default: -1

  • quiet (bool) – print confirmation messages to stdout default: False

partrace.create_particle(mesh, x0, y0, z0=0, a=0.01, rho_s=2.0)¶

Create a Particle object to integrate in a Mesh.

Parameters

  • mesh (Mesh) – partrace mesh object that contains disk information for the particle to move through

  • x (float) – starting location for the particle

  • y (float) – starting location for the particle

  • z (float) – starting location for the particle

  • a (float) – particle size in cm default: 0.01 cm

  • rho_s (float) – particle density in g cm-3 default: 2.0 g cm-3

partrace.create_planet(mesh, planet_no=0, name='jupiter')¶

Create a Planet object to embed in a Mesh.

Parameters

  • mesh (Mesh) – Mesh object that planet is embedded in

  • planet_no (int) – planet number to read in data from. planet is read in from mesh.fargodir/planet{planet_no}.dat. Mesh.n is used to get planet location data consistent with mesh. default: 0

  • name (str) – name of planet for tracking if there is more than one planet in mesh default: ‘planet’
